timeline.summary: An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent a search warrant application to Judge Nathan Moses of the New York State Court System on July 5, 2019. The application was attached to an email with the subject "Search Warrant Application" and included the document "2019.07.05 New York_Residence_SW.pdf." The sender’s phone number is redacted.

On January 31, 2020, an individual (USANYS) received notification that Judge Nathan had signed an order related to Jeffrey Epstein. The order was ready for pickup from the judge’s chambers, and the sender suggested arranging its immediate retrieval.

On February 3, 2020, an individual (USANYS) received an email from a judge’s clerk notifying them that an order (Epstein 6(e)) had been signed and was ready for pickup. The sender requested confirmation that the pickup had occurred and suggested sending a paralegal to retrieve it if necessary.

Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested in New Hampshire on July 2, 2020, related to an indictment charging her with facilitating Jeffrey Epstein’s abuse of minors. A bail argument is scheduled for Judge Nathan in New Hampshire, potentially remotely. The arrest will not occur in the SDNY.

Ghislaine Maxwell was indicted in United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). She was arrested in New Hampshire on July 2, 2020, at approximately 8:30 am and is expected to appear before a United States Magistrate Judge in the District of New Hampshire this afternoon. The government intends to seek her detention and anticipates requesting an appeal if denied in New Hampshire. An initial conference date is requested from Judge Nathan.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York contacted a recipient requesting assistance regarding the Ghislaine Maxwell case (USMS No. 02879-509). The original email, sent by an Assistant United States Attorney, requested permission for Ms. Maxwell to make a legal call to her defense counsel due to difficulties in reaching her. Judge Nathan had instructed the parties to file a letter by 9pm.

A letter template (2020-07-10,GMJetter to_Judge_Nathan_re_arraignment_overflow.docx) was sent from an unknown sender to an unknown recipient regarding an arraignment overflow. The document is associated with case file EFTA00026433.

On July 10, 2020, an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York requested docketing of the superseding indictment in the case of *US v. Maxwell* (S1 20 Cr. 330 (AN)). The request followed receipt of a color scan of the signed indictment from the United States Attorney's Office.  A previous email, dated July 8, 2020, indicated the grand jury return for the same case had been provided to Judge Nathan and the superseding indictment was unsealed.  The document is associated with EFTA00010965 and EFTA00010966.

An email chain discusses a draft letter to Netburn regarding a local rule (23.1) and an unsealing order. A user, [REDACTED], is experiencing technical difficulties and cannot immediately review the draft. Other individuals, [REDACTED], [REDACTED], and [REDACTED], were asked to review the draft letter within the hour. A related document, “letter to Netburn re order on unsealing,” (2020-07-22, JE, letter to Netburn re order on unsealing.docx) was attached.

On July 28, 2020, “I” sent a draft document, “2020-07-27,_GMJetter to_Judge_Nathan_re_protective_order.docx,” to “ale.” The sender apologized for delays in proofing and incorporating edits and expressed willingness to accept suggestions or changes. The document is identified as EFTA00031210.

Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., represented by Jeffrey S. Pagliuca, are requesting Judge Nathan’s permission to refer to and attach discovery materials (the “Unsealing Materials”) related to two settled civil cases involving Ghislaine Maxwell to the appeal in *U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell* (No. 15 Civ. 7433). The Unsealing Materials consist of ex parte pleadings, transcripts, and rulings from the government’s efforts to obtain discovery. They argue the materials are not confidential under the Protective Order and cite a Second Circuit case supporting public access. They are requesting the government agree to the disclosure and are working under a deadline set by Judge Preska to discuss this issue.

On August 17, 2020, Nicole Simmons of Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C. sent a communication to Judge Nathan regarding a request to modify a protective order in the case of *United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330 [AJN]). The communication included attachments, including a letter motion, affidavit, and exhibits (Ex._1 through Ex._10) filed under seal at the request of Jeffrey S. Pagliuca.

A request was submitted to Judge Nathan in the United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330 (MN)) to modify a protective order currently under seal. The request, originating from Jeffrey S. Pagliuca and supported by Nicole Simmons of Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., included Ms. Maxwell's letter motion, affidavit, and several exhibits (Ex._1 through Ex._10). The attachments were filed on August 17, 2020.
A draft email was sent on August 19, 2020, to Judge Nathan regarding the unsealing of materials related to case EFTA00028552. The email is attached as a .docx file.

A legal brief, titled “BRIEF, on behalf of Appellant Ghislaine Maxwell,” was filed in the 2d Circuit Court regarding the case *v. Maxwell* (Docket No. 20-02413). Sigrid McCawley of Boies Schiller Flexner LLP sent the brief to Deborah Knowlton. If Judge Nathan denies a motion to modify the protective order, Maxwell’s attorneys intend to appeal to the Second Circuit and seek consolidation with the appeal from Judge Preska’s order. The brief was filed on August 20, 2020, and entered into the court record on the same date.

The email, dated September 4, 2020, from the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York to Christian Everdel, Mark S. Cohen, Laura Menninger, and Jeff Pagliuca, proposes redactions to defense letters dated August 24, 2020, related to case number 20 Cr. 330 (AJN). The proposed redactions are submitted per Judge Nathan's order and attached as PDFs. The sender requests confirmation of acceptance.

A letter, submitted by the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, is attached for Judge Nathan’s consideration. The letter is a request to file ex parte and under seal, pursuant to Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 16(d)(1), related to the case *US v. Maxwell*, 20 Cr. 330 (MN).

On September 16, 2020, the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York sent a letter to Judge Nathan J. Alison Nathan requesting that a government letter related to the case *US v. Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN)* be filed ex parte and under seal. This request followed a memo endorsement order from Judge Nathan dated September 15, 2020, which authorized the temporary sealing of the letter. Juan Ruiz Toro, a law clerk to Judge Nathan, initially sent a letter to Nathan NYSD Chambers on September 14, 2020, requesting Judge Nathan’s consideration of a government letter for the same purpose.

On September 17, 2020, Juan Ruiz Toro, Law Clerk to Judge Alison J. Nathan, sent a memo endorsement signed by Judge Nathan regarding the case *US v. Maxwell*, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN), which was to be filed under seal.  On September 15, 2020, Judge Nathan initially sent a memo endorsement requesting a letter be filed ex parte and under seal.  On September 14, 2020, an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York submitted the letter for Judge Nathan’s consideration, also requesting it be filed ex parte and under seal. The documents were attached to emails exchanged between the involved parties.

A correspondence was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] regarding a letter dated September 28, 2020, titled "GM letter to Judge Nathan re discovery from other agencies v2.rc.docx." The sender made minor edits and added comments to the document, identified as EFTA00031975.

An email chain discusses revisions to a document titled “2020-09-28 GM letter to Judge Nathan re discovery from other agencies v2.rc.docx.”  [REDACTED] entities (USANYS) exchanged multiple emails requesting and receiving edits and comments from [REDACTED] regarding the document. The document itself was attached.

An email thread, dated September 28, 2020, discusses a draft letter to Judge Nathan regarding a discovery related to Maxwell. The email was sent between multiple redacted individuals and contained an attached message titled “RELDraft_letter to_Judge_Nathan_re_Maxwell_discovety.msg”. The email thread referenced the file EFTA00023692.

A letter dated September 30, 2020, from “S(USANYS)” to Judge Nathan regarding discovery requests from other agencies was sent. The letter is attached as “2020-09-28_GM _letter to_Judge_Nathan_re_discovery_ftom_other_agencies_v2…docx”. The sender requested feedback.
A letter dated October 7, 2020, was sent by [REDACTED] to Judge Nathan regarding discovery from other agencies. The letter is attached to an email from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] (EFTA00029199).

An email chain originating from the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York discusses a matter labeled “PBPD.” The email chain includes a letter dated October 7, 2020, from a government entity to Judge Nathan regarding discovery from other agencies, and a PDF document named Pa—gesicom_PI3 -76-2. The email correspondence involves multiple redacted USANYS individuals.

On October 30, 2020, multiple individuals (USANYS, [REDACTED]) discussed a delay in producing discovery related to the US v. Epstein case. The delay stemmed from significant processing time required for data received from FedEx, specifically 1.2 million records currently being imaged and processed. Hard drives containing productions (SDNYPROD008-014) were being sent to SDNY via FedEx, with the earliest images available on November 2nd.  A key concern was the unlikelihood of meeting the November 9th deadline, potentially requiring explanation to the Court and impacting the team’s workload under Judge Nathan.  The sender, Nick Koontz, indicated a possible timeline of Tuesday for a more concrete estimate.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent a briefing and Judge Nathan’s order to [REDACTED] regarding a litigation concerning the disclosure of victim names identified in an indictment by number. The litigation stemmed from a previous discussion with VOC chiefs about a prior case before Judge Nathan. Attached documents included a briefing and the Judge’s order denying a defense motion for victim identities.

On November 19, 2020, a letter was submitted in support of Ghislaine Maxwell’s bail application. The author claims the Ghislaine Maxwell they know is a “wonderful and loving” person, differing from the individual accused in criminal charges. The author attributes the intense media attention surrounding Maxwell to the arrest and death of Jeffrey Epstein and cites examples of conspiracy theories and harassment. They express concerns about constant media intrusion and threats, detailing instances of harmful online content and stalking. The author asserts Maxwell’s innocence, denies the allegations, and states her desire to remain in the U.S. to clear her name, citing a desire to avoid appearing to flee and a preference for proximity to New York.

On November 23, 2020, an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent a final letter to Judge Nathan regarding a matter concerning Maxwell. The letter was attached as a .docx file. The Assistant Attorney requested confirmation of the accuracy of the letter and requested responses to two questions regarding Maxwell’s situation: a staff member’s continued employment despite a COVID-19 positive status and a staff member taking photographs of Maxwell’s cell.  Additionally, Maxwell reported concerns about her mental health due to surveillance, including nighttime light shining into her eyes and increased searches. The Assistant Attorney relayed these concerns to the recipient, deferring to the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) for decisions regarding safety and security.

It detailed conversations with MDC legal counsel about the defendant’s situation. A COVID-19 outbreak led to a 14-day quarantine for Maxwell, during which she was permitted standard quarantine privileges (cell, daily checks, limited access, and use of a laptop for discovery review - 13 hours daily). *   **Continued Updates (December 4, 2020 & January 15, 2021):** The Government continued to report on Maxwell’s conditions, emphasizing consistent access to discovery (13 hours daily, seven days a week across both a desktop and laptop), regular video-teleconference calls with her attorneys (five hours per weekday), and the continuation of standard MDC procedures including searches, food service, and water provision. The government’s legal counsel noted that MDC staff monitored Maxwell’s health and weight.  The MDC legal team responded to concerns raised by defense counsel regarding access to the laptop and in-person visits, but without reaching an agreement. *   **Court Order (January 25, 2021):**  Judge Nathan ordered the Government to provide 60-day written updates regarding Maxwell’s confinement, focusing on access to legal materials and searches.  The Court denied the BOP’s request to compel Warden Tellez to appear and respond directly. *   **Final Update (February 4, 2021):** The Government provided a detailed response to the Judge's January order, reinforcing that Maxwell continues to receive the maximum permitted access to discovery and legal communications, detailing standard MDC procedures (including searches, healthcare, and water provision), and addressing previous concerns regarding monitoring and surveillance. The government also reported on the defendant's recent COVID-19 vaccination status.

On November 25, 2020, Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP sent an email to Judge Nathan regarding a renewed bail motion in the case of *U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330). The email included a letter intended to be filed under seal and submitted to the court and all counsel, referencing Section 2(B) of Judge Nathan’s Individual Practices in Criminal Cases. The letter was attached and addressed to the court and legal representatives involved in the case.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York submitted an application for a search warrant (EFTA00018615) and supporting documents to Judge Wang. The application included four exhibits and a proposed search warrant. The Attorney corrected a previous submission that mistakenly included Judge Nathan’s name instead of Judge Wang’s. The Agent was available to swear out the warrant and could be contacted via email or cellphone. A related document (EFTA00018616) contained similar information.

Epstein case. *   The team is experiencing significant delays (1-2 months) in receiving processed data from Relativity. *   Approximately 1.2 million records are being imaged and will be available for production starting Monday, November 2nd. *   Hard drives containing productions SDNYPROD008 through SDNYPROD014 are being sent to SDNY via FedEx. *   A key concern is the potential impact on deadlines, particularly the November 9th deadline, and the possibility of requiring a court explanation. *   The sender anticipates a more concrete update early next week.

The email chain discusses a significant delay in the processing of data for the US v. Epstein case. Approximately 1.2 million records are being imaged and processed by PAE, with FedEx involvement. The initial deadline of November 9th is now considered unachievable. The team is concerned about the impact on discovery timelines and potential issues with Judge Nathan. Hard drives containing productions (SDNYPROD008-013) are being sent to Sony via FedEx. An update is expected early next week, potentially requiring a broader explanation to the court.

A draft letter was prepared in response to requests for redactions and an in camera proceeding from Maxwell, related to the case file EFTA00032013. The letter references Judge Nathan’s order and attached filings. A minor edit was made to an attached document.

On December 4, 2020, an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent a replacement drive to Ghislaine Maxwell at the Metropolitan Detention Center, Brooklyn. The drive was intended to replace one that Maxwell had broken. A letter to Judge Nathan was attached, requesting a correction to a track change on page 2 before submission.  A staff attorney from the Department of Justice’s Federal Bureau of Prisons also sent a letter detailing the shipment and requesting the return of the broken drive.  A paralegal specialist at the U.S. Attorney’s Office provided the mailing address.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York is coordinating the delivery of a replacement drive to Ghislaine Maxwell at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) in Brooklyn, New York. A previous drive was broken. The Assistant U.S. Attorney requests confirmation of Maxwell’s access to the new drive and the return shipment of the broken drive to the U.S. Attorney’s Office in New York. There is a concern about a track change on a second page that needs to be addressed before submission to Judge Nathan. Correspondence between the Assistant U.S. Attorney and a Staff Attorney from the Department of Justice/Federal Bureau of Prisons is included.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York is arranging for a replacement drive to be sent to Ghislaine Maxwell. A previous drive was broken, and the recipient is instructed to mail the broken drive back to the U.S. Attorney’s Office. There is a concern about a track change on a second page that needs to be addressed before submission to Judge Nathan.  Multiple individuals and offices are involved including the Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Prisons, and a Paralegal Specialist.

An email chain discusses the delivery of a replacement drive to Ghislaine Maxwell. A track change on page 2 needs to be corrected before submission to Judge Nathan. A letter to Judge Nathan is attached. A replacement drive is being sent via FedEx, and the broken drive needs to be returned to the U.S. Attorney’s Office, SDNY. The email chain includes individuals from the U.S. Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Prisons, and the U.S. Attorney’s Office.

*   An email chain discusses a replacement drive for Ghislaine Maxwell being sent to the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) in Brooklyn. *   The drive is replacing one that was broken. *   A request is made to ensure Maxwell receives the new drive and to mail the broken drive back to the U.S. Attorneys Office, SDNY. *   There is a note about a track change needing to be addressed before submission to Judge Nathan. *   A call to discuss issues is offered.

On December 4, 2020, Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP sent a draft letter to Judge Nathan regarding a briefing schedule. The letter was attached as a .DOCX file. He requested confirmation from the recipient ([REDACTED]) that there were no comments before sending the letter within the hour. The email also included images and a confidentiality notice.

*   A drive is being shipped by the U.S. Attorney’s Office, Southern District of New York, to the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn. *   The broken drive needs to be returned to the U.S. Attorneys Office, SDNY in New York, NY 10007. *   There’s a request to ensure Ghislaine Maxwell receives the new drive. *   A track change was identified on page 2 and needs to be addressed before submission to Judge Nathan.

On December 8, 2020, Christian R. Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP submitted a renewed bail motion and redacted exhibits (A-E) to Judge Nathan in the case of U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). The documents were filed under seal.

Two contractors ([REDACTED] and [REDACTED]) are handling the production of materials related to the US v. Epstein case. Two hard drives containing copies of productions 15 & 16 were received from PAE. The vendor is stamping and exporting portions of the production data (parts 1-6) from Relativity. Part 4 is partially stamped, and the vendor is requesting a potential extension from Judge Nathan. The contractor is monitoring the progress and coordinating with other parties regarding the delivery of the hard drives.

Sigrid McCawley sent a statement to Boies Schiller Flexner regarding Ghislaine Maxwell’s case. The statement expresses concern about Maxwell’s potential release on bail, citing her history of abuse, manipulative behavior, disregard for others, and potential to flee.  She believes Maxwell is a psychopath and fears she will continue to harm others if released. The sender requests the statement be submitted as a separate PDF with appropriate attribution and suggests a letter addressed to Judge Nathan as the most suitable format.

An email chain discusses a response filed by USANYS to Ghislaine Maxwell’s renewed bail motion. The response was initially filed under seal with proposed redactions due to a court order. A timeframe of at least two days is anticipated before the response appears on the docket due to the defense’s 24-hour objection period to the redactions. The email thread includes requests for updates and a copy of the response, referencing Judge Nathan’s scheduling of a ruling and the VW website.

Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP sent an email to Judge Nathan regarding a typographical error in a reply brief for the case *U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330). The email requested approval to correct the error on pages 1 and 8 of the memorandum.  He attached both the unredacted and redacted versions of the memorandum, along with exhibits A-B, to be filed under seal. The email also included a cover letter and confidentiality notices.

An Assistant United States Attorney is requesting a call to discuss a situation involving Maxwell’s confinement at the MDC. The defense filed a letter demanding a court appearance regarding Maxwell’s conditions, which Judge Nathan endorsed with an order for a conference update by December 12th. The request for the call is to discuss this matter before the Thanksgiving holiday.

Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP sent a letter, attached as a PDF, to Judge Nathan regarding the sealing of Ghislaine Maxwell’s renewed bail motion in the case U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330 (MN)). The letter was to be filed under seal and submitted to the Court and all counsel according to Judge Nathan’s Individual Practices in Criminal Cases.

This document is a transcript of a phone call between defense counsel (Sternheim and Everdell) and MDC legal counsel regarding a female inmate, GM, held at a Bureau of Prisons facility (MDC). Key issues discussed include: *   **Excessive Surveillance:** GM is subjected to constant surveillance, including a second camera pointed into the visiting room, frequent wake-up calls, and intrusive searches (including strip searches) that are significantly more extensive than those given to other inmates. *   **Differential Treatment:** GM receives enhanced privileges (extended computer access, shower, phone, TV) due to her situation, leading to concerns she is effectively in solitary confinement. This treatment is driven, in part, by the need to review a large volume of discovery. *   **Requests for Change:** Sternheim requests the Warden be brought before Judge Nathan to explain the justification for the surveillance and searching, specifically requesting the removal of the second camera and a reduction in intrusive searches to match those of other inmates. *   **Day Room Concerns:** The conversation repeatedly returns to the issue of GM being housed in a day room, which would mitigate many of the current problems, but is not being implemented. *   **Discovery Access:** There is a substantial amount of discovery material for GM to review, and the defense is seeking an extension to facilitate this process. The overall tone reflects frustration with the BOP's handling of GM's case and a strong advocacy for her rights and well-being.

Maurene, an Assistant United States Attorney, responded to Christian Everdell’s email regarding redactions related to a case. They agreed that no redactions were necessary based on Judge Nathan’s opinion and order denying bail. Maurene attached a draft joint letter to the court for Christian to finalize, requesting any proposed revisions.

Bobbi C. Sternheim, Esq., directed Ghislaine Maxwell to receive access to her laptop on weekends and holidays, as ordered by Judge Alison J. Nathan. The court order, attached to an email, mandated the Bureau of Prisons to provide this access during permitted discovery review hours.

Bobbi Sternheim, an attorney, is contacting recipients regarding a court order (EFTA00021732) demanding Ghislaine Maxwell’s access to her laptop on weekends and holidays. Initially, MDC legal counsel confirmed they would comply. However, a security detail officer, Officer Regan, refused to grant access, stating “I don’t care.” Sternheim intends to notify Judge Nathan of this violation and urges immediate compliance to avoid contempt of court. The court order itself (EFTA00021734) explicitly directs the Bureau of Prisons to provide access. Sternheim's office is operating remotely due to COVID-19 restrictions, utilizing email and fax for communication.

A legal dispute arose regarding Ghislaine Maxwell’s access to a laptop during weekends and holidays while incarcerated. Initially, a court order (Judge Nathan) granted Maxwell access, but the MDC (likely a prison department) initially claimed no objection. However, following a communication from Maxwell’s attorney, Bobbi C. Sternheim, it was revealed that MDC intended to comply, but a security detail unexpectedly denied access, citing a lack of concern for the court order. Sternheim threatened to inform the judge of the violation and urged immediate compliance to avoid contempt of court. The communication chain highlights a breakdown in communication and a potential disregard for the court’s directives.

The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, presided over by Alison J. Nathan, denied the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) Brooklyn’s request to vacate an order regarding Ghislaine Maxwell’s confinement. The order stemmed from concerns raised by defense counsel about Maxwell’s limited access to discovery. Despite these concerns, Maxwell has been granted access to a government-provided laptop for 13 hours daily, five days a week, and access to the MDC’s discovery computers. She also maintains regular contact with her legal counsel via video-teleconference and telephone.

A communication from an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York to [REDACTED] regarding “Maxwell motions 1 of 3.” The communication includes attachments: a zipped file dated 1.25.2021 containing filings, and a cover letter dated 1.25.2021 to Judge Nathan regarding pretrial motions. The case identifier is EFTA00011444.

On February 2, 2021, an Assistant United States Attorney (USA) from the Southern District of New York sent an email to update the court regarding Maxwell’s case. Judge Nathan denied a motion to vacate an order regarding Maxwell’s access to a laptop. The USA requested a call to discuss an update letter due Friday, February 5th, covering topics including discovery access, legal mail access, legal email access, communication with legal counsel, and search frequency. The email attached a document outlining these specific areas for update.

Laura Menninger, on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell, submitted objections to redactions proposed by the government in their Omnibus Response and Exhibit 5 related to the U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330). Attached documents included a letter detailing the objections, proposed redactions, and supporting exhibits.

Ghislaine Maxwell’s legal team, Haddon Morgan and Foreman, objects to redactions proposed by the government in their response to pre-trial motions in the United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell case. Specifically, they challenge redactions in the omnibus response (pages 1-128 and 187-88), Exhibit 5, and portions of Maxwell’s sealed deposition testimony (pages 129-134). The objections center on the government’s attempts to conceal inaccurate statements by a prosecutor, circumvented legal precedent, and protect information that should be publicly accessible due to its connection to a criminal case and Maxwell's right to an open trial. The team argues the redactions impede transparency and accountability in the judicial process, particularly concerning the Accuser-2’s diary and Maxwell’s deposition testimony.

*   A legal team (Chris Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP) is proposing redactions to Exhibit 11 and their letter dated March 9, 2021, regarding redactions. *   The redactions are based on a court order (Judge Nathan’s) to redact portions of deposition transcripts and related documents that were originally filed in a defamation case and remain sealed. *   Specifically, they are requesting redactions to include “[Minor Victim-2]” on page 134 and to redact quotations/references from a document (Exhibit H) that is also under seal. *   The opposing legal team (EFTA00019475) initially questioned the need for the redactions but ultimately agrees to the proposed redactions, deferring to Chris’s decision on the redactions of Exhibit H. *   They are scheduling a meeting to discuss the redactions further.

On March 9, 2021, Laura Menninger sent a letter and attachments to Judge Nathan regarding objections to the government’s proposed redactions in the U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330). The attachments included Ms. Maxwell’s objections and her proposed redactions for pages 1-128 of a document. The correspondence involved multiple individuals and law firms, including Cohen & Gresser LLP, and referenced Rule 2(B) of the court’s individual rules.

An email chain discusses a briefing regarding the suppression of victim identification in the Epstein/Maxwell extradition case. A request was made for a document outlining previously highlighted information related to this suppression, specifically in response to a Canadian Justice Department’s request for a “publication ban” to prevent defense counsel from identifying victims. An attached document, a letter from GMJetter to Judge Nathan, is referenced.

Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP sent a filing to Judge Nathan regarding the U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330). The filing includes redacted and unredacted versions of Ms. Maxwell’s reply memoranda and accompanying exhibits in support of her pretrial motions, submitted pursuant to Rule 2(B) of the court’s rules. A redacted cover letter is being filed on the public docket.

Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP sent an email to Judge Nathan regarding the filing of redacted and unredacted versions of Ghislaine Maxwell’s reply memoranda and exhibits in support of her pretrial motions in the case U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330). The attachments included a zip file containing the memoranda and exhibits, along with several image files. A redacted cover letter was filed on the public docket.

An email exchange between Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP and an unknown recipient regarding proposed redactions to Exhibit 11. The redactions, as outlined in Judge Nathan’s order, target quotations and references from a previously filed, sealed document (Exhibit H). The sender seeks confirmation from the recipient regarding whether the redactions should remain in place, deferring to the recipient's decision. Attached documents include proposed redactions and the original opposition brief.

On April 13, 2021, Christian Everdell, acting on behalf of defense counsel, requested Judge Nathan’s authorization to allow the introduction of electronic devices into the courthouse for evidence viewing. Jeff Pagliuca, counsel, had previously sent a request to Judge Nathan for permission to bring electronic devices and equipment into the courthouse. An order signed by Judge Nathan was attached to the initial email.

Law Clerk Nathan Chambers responded to David Oscar Markus’s request for permission to bring electronic devices into the courthouse for the U.S. v. Maxwell case (20-Cr-330). Chambers stated that all communications with Judge Nathan must be docketed on ECF unless a request to seal is made, and Judge Nathan does not issue electronic device orders for attorneys who haven’t appeared on ECF. He provided a link to the form for the order authorizing electronic devices. Markus, representing Ghislaine Maxwell, requested permission to bring his cell phone and laptop to the April 23rd arraignment and offered to provide a proposed order.

An email was sent from an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York to Judge Nathan, attaching an opinion addressing pretrial motions. The email indicates the opinion pertains to litigation.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent an email on April 17, 2021, attached an opinion from Judge Nathan addressing pretrial motions. The opinion was related to case EFTA00038559.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York requested a call to discuss a judge’s opinion regarding evidence related to Maxwell. The opinion requires the government to confirm whether they view evidence supporting Maxwell’s interpretation of the NPA as material to disclose, and to confirm if such evidence has been disclosed. The request was made to schedule a call this weekend. Emails were exchanged coordinating a meeting time.

Jeff Pagliuca sent a collection of documents, including responses to a motion to quash, subpoenas, and a letter regarding redactions, to Laura Mennin, Nicole Simmons, and Sabina Mariella. Sigrid McCawley requested confirmation that these materials could be sent to the Government for review and potential redaction requests, following Judge Nathan’s order.

On April 22, 2021, Laura Menninger sent an email requesting a redaction of client names and case numbers from a letter motion submitted to Judge Nathan in the case of *US v. Maxwell*. The motion sought a 120 or 180-day adjournment of the trial, citing Rule of Professional Conduct 1.6, which prohibits lawyers from revealing confidential client information, even if publicly available. The email referenced previous correspondence and attached the redacted Letter Motion. The court instructed counsel to file either the redacted or unredacted version of the letter on the public docket.

The email chain discusses a request for a 120 or 180-day adjournment of trial in the case of *US v. Maxwell*. Counsel for Ms. Maxwell requested redaction of other clients’ names and case numbers from a letter motion, citing Rule of Professional Conduct 1.6 to protect client confidentiality. The motion references relevant case law regarding a lawyer’s duty of confidentiality, even when information is publicly available. The court directed counsel to file either a redacted or unredacted version of the letter motion on the public docket.

A legal team (BOIES SCHILLER FLEXNER LLP) is responding to a request from “USANYS” regarding redactions to documents related to a case overseen by Judge Nathan. The team is proposing redactions and seeking confirmation that the documents can be sent to the government. Attached documents include proposed redactions and responses to subpoenas, all stemming from a request for materials related to the Maxwell Rule 17(c) subpoena.

Bobbi Sternheim, counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, is requesting that Maxwell not be brought to court before noon on April 23, 2021, for her 2:30 pm arraignment. The government does not oppose this request.

An order, signed by Judge Nathan, has been filed under seal in the case of US v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20-cr-330). The order was attached as 20cr330_Sealed_Order_4.23.21.pdf and sent by The Chambers of the Hon. Alison J. Nathan on April 23, 2021.

Judge Nathan issued an opinion regarding Maxwell’s pretrial motions. She granted Maxwell’s motion to sever the perjury counts and denied the remaining motions, with the exception of the suppression motions concerning the Boies Schiller materials, which she deferred to a later decision.

On April 28, 2021, Laura Menninger (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C.) and Bobbi Sternheim contacted Jeff Pagliuca and Mark S. Cohen regarding the US v. Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). Menninger proposed sending a position on defense disclosures by email and offered a call for discussion, aiming for a joint filing on Monday. She also requested input on a proposed schedule for witness statement disclosures, referencing Judge Nathan’s Order 250. Furthermore, they planned to submit a letter to Judge Nathan requesting exclusion of Speedy Trial Act time related to the S2 Indictment, pending the suppression motion and trial date, and sought consent from the defense counsel to this exclusion.

On April 29, 2021, an Assistant United States Attorney (USANYS) forwarded an email from [REDACTED] regarding a Judge Nathan order in the Maxwell case. The order directed the MDC to take specific steps by April 30, 2021. The USANYS planned to send the order to AJN chambers with standard email language and offered a call to discuss the order.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York is drafting a response letter to an attached document. They intend to send a draft to defense counsel tonight, with a goal of filing it tomorrow, as directed by Judge Nathan. The attorney expresses concerns about the potential impact of redaction/intervention requests due to the anticipated high volume of individuals seeking to review and redact documents.

An email chain discusses a draft letter being prepared in response to a sealed order (20cr330_Sealed_Order_4.23.21.pdf). The email indicates a planned review of the draft by April 29, 2021, with the intention of sending it to defense counsel and potentially filing it the following day. Concerns are expressed about the potential volume of redaction/intervention requests related to third-party privacy interests. The correspondence involves the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

On April 29, 2021, Ori from (USANYS) contacted individuals regarding a request from Maxwell’s counsel challenging the court’s order regarding Ms. Maxwell’s sleeping conditions, specifically the 15-minute light surveillance. Bobbi Sternheim attached a courtesy copy of a filed ECF concerning the matter. The communication included a Covid-19 notice detailing the Law Offices of Bobbi C. Sternheim’s remote operations during the pandemic.

A series of emails between individuals at the USANYS (Southern District of New York) discuss a letter regarding a case. The letter was updated and circulated among legal team members for review. Concerns were raised regarding redaction requests due to potential volume of individuals seeking to review and redact documents. A draft of the letter is being prepared for defense counsel, with the intention of filing it tomorrow.

An email chain discusses coordinating a meeting and confer regarding the US v. Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330). Laura Menninger proposes sending a position on defense disclosures by email and scheduling a subsequent call. She requests input on excluding Speedy Trial Act time for the 52 Indictment, specifically requesting consent from the recipient to do so while the suppression motion remains pending. A request is made for a meeting to discuss a proposed schedule for witness statement disclosures, referencing Judge Nathan’s Order 250.

The provided text is a series of email exchanges regarding a US v. Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). Key points include: *   **Meeting and Conferring:** Discussions are centered around scheduling a call to “meet and confer” regarding witness disclosures, a Speedy Trial Act exclusion request, and a letter to the judge. *   **Proposed Letter:** Laura Menninger drafted a letter for the government to send regarding defense disclosures and the Speedy Trial Act. *   **Speedy Trial Request:** The government intends to request an exclusion of time under the Speedy Trial Act, particularly in light of the pending suppression motion and potential trial date changes. *   **UK Counsel Communication:** Discussions involve coordinating with UK counsel regarding a letter to the judge, with concerns about providing legal procedure advice. *   **Phone Tree:** The possibility of establishing a “phone tree” for coordination is discussed.
Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP sent a letter to Judge Nathan, filed on the docket, regarding hard drives. The letter is attached as "2021.04.30_Letter_to_Judge_Nathan_re_Hard_Drives.pdf".

An order was issued by Judge Nathan regarding the Maxwell case, directing the MDC to take specific steps by April 30, 2021. The order is attached as 2021.04.29_AJN_Order_re_MDC.pdf and was sent by an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York.

An email chain discusses edits to a draft response to a Judge Nathan order regarding Rule 17 subpoenas. Attachments include a letter to AJN, briefs by BSF/GM, and Judge Nathan’s order. The sender is requesting review of the draft before it is sent to senior leadership (“chiefs”). The email exchange occurred between May 2, 2021, and April 30, 2021.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent an email regarding Rule 17 subpoenas related to Maxwell’s requests. The email included a draft response, Judge Nathan’s order, letters from Maxwell and Boies Schiller, and a document outlining proposed redactions to the subpoenas.

A memorandum endorsement signed by Judge Nathan, related to the case 20-cr-330, US v Maxwell, was filed on the public docket. The memorandum was sent from The Chambers of the Hon. Alison J. Nathan to [REDACTED].

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent emails regarding Rule 17 subpoenas related to Maxwell’s requests. The emails included attachments of a Judge Nathan order, a draft response, letters from Maxwell and Boies Schiller, and a previous order concerning pretrial motions. Redaction analysis was performed on the document.

The United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York is sharing a letter regarding a case, *US v. Maxwell*, with counsel. The letter, drafted by Lara, an Assistant United States Attorney, was issued in response to a Judge Nathan order (Dkt. No. 257) requesting input on potential redactions of private medical information before public filing. The Government believes no redactions are necessary but is seeking confirmation from counsel.

An email chain discusses Maxwell’s case, specifically a ruling regarding his confinement conditions rather than a bail order. David Markus intends to file a renewed motion for bond in the Second Circuit based on the Friday ruling. Maxwell’s attorney sent an email referencing the ruling and questioning the purpose of a potential new appeal.

A memorandum of law from the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York was sent to Judge Nathan in opposition to the defendant Ghislaine Maxwell’s supplemental pretrial motions. The Government does not request redactions to the memorandum. The sender indicates that the electronic case filing system requires the original motion to be on the docket before an opposition brief can be filed, and they will promptly file their opposition once the defense motion is publicly available.

Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP sent an email to Judge Nathan on May 28, 2021, regarding a reply memorandum submitted by Ghislaine Maxwell in support of her supplemental pretrial motions related to the S2 Superseding Indictment in the U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330). The email included a cover letter and the reply memorandum, which were filed under seal. A confidentiality notice was also included within the email.

Ghislaine Maxwell is receiving enhanced access to discovery at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC), including 13 hours daily to review documents on both MDC and government-provided computers, and email access with her attorneys. She has daily access to a day room with computer, television, phone, and shower. She is permitted outdoor recreation and has five hours of weekly video-teleconference (VTC) calls with her counsel, all conducted in private rooms with cameras that do not record audio. In-person attorney visits are also permitted with similar audio-recording measures. Standard MDC security protocols, including pat-downs, mouth searches, strip searches, body scans, and fifteen-minute wellness checks, are consistently applied. MDC medical and psychology staff monitor her daily health, with her last documented weight being 138 pounds.

The document is a series of email exchanges between U.S. Attorney’s Office personnel regarding a suppression hearing related to Maxwell and a related case. Key points include: *   Requests for documents, specifically the original application to Judge Sweet and responses. *   Discussion about multiple motions in limine (MOLs) being filed to evade page limits. *   Confusion regarding multiple memos of law associated with Maxwell. *   Attachments of briefs, transcripts, and exhibits related to the suppression motion. *   Scheduling a meeting to discuss the matter and determine a suitable time to meet. *   Reference to Judge Nathan’s intention to resolve the suppression motions “at a later time” ahead of trial.

A letter was sent from an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York to Minnesota regarding a prosecution team. The letter is attached to an email dated June 25, 2021, and includes a finalized letter to Judge Nathan concerning discovery from other agencies. The sender's contact information includes the USANYS and their location in New York, NY.

On July 30, 2021, David Oscar Markus emailed the Chambers of Judge Nathan regarding the United States v. Maxwell 20-Cr-330 case. Markus, who hadn't entered an appearance in the proceeding, responded to a government letter and court order requesting a response. He requested the email be filed on the public docket and offered an alternative filing method if preferred. He copied government and defense counsel on the email.

An Assistant United States Attorney notified Sigrid McCawley and David about a recent order (2021.07.30_Order Regarding_Local_Rule_23.1.pdf) from Judge Nathan concerning Local Criminal Rule 23.1. The rule applies to counsel of record and attorneys associated with criminal cases. The full text of the local SDNY rules is available on the court’s website.

A United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent an email regarding a recent order from Judge Nathan concerning Local Criminal Rule 23.1. The rule applies to counsel of record and attorneys associated with criminal cases, including those representing witnesses. The order and full SDNY rules are available on the court’s website, and inquiries about the rule or order are welcome.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent an email to Jack Scarola on August 2, 2021, regarding a new order from Judge Nathan concerning Local Criminal Rule 23.1. The rule applies to counsel of record and attorneys associated with a criminal case, including those representing witnesses. The order and full SDNY rules are available on the court’s website.

A United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent an email to Gloria and Mariann Wang regarding a recent order from Judge Nathan concerning Local Criminal Rule 23.1. The rule applies to both counsel of record and attorneys associated with a criminal case. The order and full text of the SDNY rules are available on the court's website.

An email exchange concerning opposition to a Bill of Particulars in a case involving Ghislaine Maxwell. The email discusses Judge Nathan’s denial of a motion for a Bill of Particulars and includes attached documents detailing two rounds of pretrial motions from the government and the defense. The sender requests to review the attached documents.

On August 17, 2021, Assistant United States Attorney Andrew sent a letter to the defense regarding Judge Nathan's ruling. Judge Nathan denied Maxwell’s supplemental motions and presumed the prosecution would provide the identities of Maxwell’s uncharged co-conspirators because no objections were raised. The attached letter explains that the prosecution does not intend to provide these identities. Judge Nathan’s opinion, including footnote 1 on page 12, was also attached for reference.

An email from [REDACTED] to EFTA00027390 requests updating the victim website with dates from a judge’s order regarding the Maxwell trial. The order, attached as 2021.08.27_Order re_Maxwell_trial_schedule.pdf, was issued by Judge Nathan.

An email was sent regarding the Maxwell trial schedule. Judge Nathan issued an order establishing new trial dates. The sender requested a new victim notification letter be prepared, following a previous trip to New York for the defendant and their family.

An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] regarding a protective order. The email attached Judge Nathan’s opinion, referencing the cases of *Martindell* and *Chemical Bank*. The case number is EFTA00013172.

Stemheim) regarding the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (MN)). The government intends to refer Jefferey Epstein as a co-conspirator. The communication is governed by a Protective Order dated July 31, 2020, designating the letter as confidential.

This document is a press guidance update regarding the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell, charged with conspiracy and sex trafficking related to Jeffrey Epstein’s activities. Key points include: *   The court has ruled that witnesses, who are not alleged victims, may testify under pseudonyms due to the sensitive nature of the expected testimony regarding illegal sexual abuse. *   Maxwell faces maximum penalties of five to ten years in prison per count, depending on the charge. *   A trial logistics order from Judge Nathan is attached. *   Government exhibits will be distributed through the SDNY file share. *   The trial will take place on November 23, 2021, before Judge Alison Nathan. *   Media representatives are encouraged to establish a PACER account.

On January 14, 2022, Judge Alison J. Nathan scheduled Ghislaine Maxwell’s sentencing for June 28, 2022, at 11:00 a.m. The Court delayed preparing a presentence investigation report until April 2022 and maintained the existing schedule for briefing on the new trial motion and other post-verdict motions. The Government was instructed to indicate by January 18, 2022, whether it seeks an exclusion of time under the Speedy Trial Act for the perjury counts, along with the basis for that request.

*   A memorandum and order was issued by Judge Nathan regarding post-trial motions in the case of USA v. Maxwell (Case 1:20-cr-00330-AJN). *   All post-trial motions were resolved, with the court denying the defendant’s motions related to constructive amendment, variance, and pre-indictment delay. *   The court ruled that Counts One, Three, Four, and Six of the indictment are to be pursued for conviction due to multiplicity with Count Three. *   The defendant’s sentencing date remains scheduled for June 28, 2022. *   Notifications were sent to various parties involved in the case, including attorneys and court personnel.
